keyTakeAways: The Louvre Museum has faced repeated security breaches, including a recent heist in October 2025 where thieves stole jewelry from the Apollo Gallery in just seven minutes.
The crown of Empress Eugénie, one of the museum’s most valuable artifacts, was damaged during the heist and was found outside the museum.
Security at the Louvre has been chronically underfunded and outdated, with a Court of Auditors report from 2019–2024 noting persistent delays in updating security systems.
The museum has long-term structural problems including water leaks, overcrowding, and temperature fluctuations, which threaten artwork preservation and visitor experience.
The Louvre's visitor capacity has strained its infrastructure, leading to understaffing, poor sanitation, and public complaints over decades.
A 2024 memo from Louvre president Laurence des Cars warned of deteriorating conditions and called for urgent renovation, including a dedicated room for the 'Mona Lisa'.
French President Emmanuel Macron announced a 10-year renovation plan to expand the Louvre, including a dedicated space for the 'Mona Lisa', in response to these systemic issues.
The museum has a history of theft, including the 1911 theft of the 'Mona Lisa' and the 1983 theft of 16th-century armor, which were returned in 2021.
The 2025 heist is not isolated but part of a long-standing pattern of security and operational failures affecting the world’s most visited museum.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A recent heist at the Louvre Museum in Paris, occurring in October 2025, saw thieves break into the Apollo Gallery and steal high-value jewelry in just seven minutes. The crown of Empress Eugénie, one of the museum’s prized artifacts, was damaged during the robbery and found outside the building. This incident is not isolated; it follows a long history of theft, including the 1911 'Mona Lisa' heist and the 1983 disappearance of 16th-century armor, which was returned in 2021. The heist coincides with a broader pattern of chronic security and infrastructure failures at the museum, highlighted by a 2019–2024 Court of Auditors report that found persistent delays in updating security systems and inadequate response to structural issues such as water leaks, overcrowding, and temperature fluctuations. These problems were previously flagged by Louvre President Laurence des Cars in a 2024 memo, which called for urgent renovation. In response, French President Emmanuel Macron announced a 10-year expansion plan for the museum, including a dedicated room for the 'Mona Lisa'. The article underscores the Louvre’s vulnerability due to outdated systems, poor visitor management, and insufficient investment, raising global concerns about the security and sustainability of one of the world’s most iconic cultural institutions.
title: Jewelry heist at the Louvre is latest problem to beset France’s most famous museum
